scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-152 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-152 is a star with 0.83 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.72 times its radius. It is located 1438.64 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-152 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-152 system


Kepler-152 b

Kepler-152 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-152 b is 8.204 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-152 b is 2.790 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-152 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-152 c

Kepler-152 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.36 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-152 c is 6.296 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-152 c is 2.390 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-152 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-152, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-152 - System With 2 Exolanets
